title: Climbing Skills: Intro To Climbing
eventDescriptions: Learn the basics of climbing with support from The WELL's climbing team. Participants will go through a safety orientation, learn basic movements, and receive 1:1 instructor belays and coaching for this class. Tentative Itinerary - Introductions - How to wear a harness safely - How to tie a figure 8 knot - How to use an ATC - Belaying principles - Closing questions

title: Basic Sailing Zest Class - 01
eventDescriptions: The newest addition to our fleet, the Zest sailboat is taught using a mainsail only and can be sailed by one person (single-handed.)  It is the easiest to rig and sail, and compared to the Quest, it is more stable and easier to recover from a capsize. The Zest is 12 feet long, 5 feet wide and weighs 160 pounds.  It is our best option for practicing basic skills and sailing solo if you do not have a partner.  However, it will easily accommodate an adult and a child or two average-sized adults.

title: CANCELLED: Basic Windsurfing Class -01
eventDescriptions: This course is designed for those with little to no experience and will familiarize the student with the basic fundamentals of windsurfing. This class covers rigging, terminology, balance, stances and windsurfing theory. Instructors will utilize the latest techniques and a variety of sail sizes to decrease fatigue and help accelerate learning. Upon successful completion of this course, students will be eligible to rent these windsurfers.

title: Exposing Hidden Bias
eventDescriptions: "Join us for an important discussion that brings attention to the unconscious biases we all possess and provides some strategies for overcoming its impact in our work and relationships. Come learn about diversity & inclusion, how to recognize areas where unconscious bias may surface, identify strategies for avoiding bias, and learn of resources available for additional learning and involvement.This workshop is for those interested in building awareness of unconscious bias, or looking for a refresher.  During the workshop, we will engage with each other in sharing thoughts, perspectives, and ideas utilizing a variety of zoom tools such as unmute, hand raising, chat field, and breakout rooms.  As such, if able, you are encouraged to turn on your video to connect. Optional Prework -  In order to prepare for some rich conversation, we invite you to participate in the following:      • View the following video from Scientific American Frontiers:  www.youtube.com… • Complete the Race Implicit Association Test (IAT), and in addition, select one of the following: Gender-Career, Disability, Skin-tone, Age or Weight.  The implicit Association Tests are available at:  implicit.harvard.edu… • Read the Roots of Implicit Bias article from New York Times:  nyti.ms… For information about your workshop facilitator, Lanaya Gaberel, please visit the LinkedIn page at www.linkedin.com…"

title: Business Partners Round Table (BPRT)
eventDescriptions: Due to budget constraints, Financial Services will be unable to provide refreshments. Please feel free to bring your own. Financial Services is committed to the delivery of the highest quality service in support of University goals. We know that the key to our success is partnering with campus service clients. Working with our University partners, we hope to make the business environment easy to navigate by clearly communicating requirements, simplifying procedures, learning about your needs, and working to design mutually satisfactory work processes. Through the Business Partners Round Table, we hope to provide the most current information to help campus business partners succeed in their jobs. Draft and Final Agenda disseminated via the BPRT Mailing list prior to meeting. For questions or reasonable accommodations please contact Jeanne Brewster at brewster@csus.edu at least 5 business days before the event.

title: FOTA 2025! 50 Years of Chicano Theatre, Manuel Pickett, Artistic Director, Teatro Espejo
eventDescriptions: Teatro Espejo has been bringing theatre to the community for more than 40 years. Under the guidance of Artistic Director and Professor Emeritus, Manuel José Pickett, Teatro Espejo has remained dedicated to offering opportunities to teatristas of all ages and skill levels. Our seasons honor the rich legacy and history of teatro by producing important classic works from the Chicano/Latinx theatre cannon, and groundbreaking contemporary works by new, emerging, and established playwrights representing the Latinx diaspora. title: Carlsen Center Startup Board Development Series
eventDescriptions: The Carlsen Center for Innovation & Entrepreneurship is excited to offer the Startup Board Development Series which will enable you, as a founder, to unlock the hidden power of startup and advisory boards. This three-part series will be led by Kim Box, Independent Board Director and Advisor as well as Carlsen Center Advisory Board Member. Workshop 1 – Board Overview (April 8th) The overview will take into consideration different stages of the company: Seed Growth Series A+ Acquisition or IPO Explore the role of a board or advisory board Support you in identifying who should be on your board The blocking and tackling of setting up a board Workshop 2 – Board Mechanics (April 15th) The focus will be on all aspects of running the board: Calendar – cadence of board meetings Who attends beyond the board members Agenda Board Packet How to effectively communicate and engage a board An effective strategy for structuring your board or advisory board Workshop 3 – Panel with Board Members and Founders (April 22nd) We will bring in a panel of board members and founders to share their real-world experience in building and serving on advisory and startup boards.

title: 04/08/2025 Lunch On The Go
eventDescriptions: Do you feel like it can be difficult to eat a nutritious meal when you’re on the go a lot? It’s not always possible to avoid eating out, and that’s okay. In this workshop, learn how to make nutritious choices when eating from a restaurant, as well as how to prepare food ahead of time that is suitable for eating on-the-go. Includes a mini cooking demonstration. We will be making a vibrant and delicious Spring Chicken Pesto Pasta Salad! Gluten free option will be available. Join our CalFresh Healthy Living student assistants for “Lunch on the Go” on Tuesday, April 8th, from 12pm-1pm at The Cove Kitchen (1st floor, The WELL). (60 minutes) Recipe: Spring Chicken Pesto Pasta Salad

title: CANCELLED: Stand Up Paddle Class - 02
eventDescriptions: Sign up for one of out stand up paddle board (SUP) clinics and see what all the excitement is about. Even if you have little experience paddling, our group SUP courses are designed using ACA level one requirements, which introduce and expose beginning paddlers to the skills, equipment and knowledge that is needed to become a successful paddle boarder. We also challenge more advanced paddlers wanting to improve their techniques on the water. Upon completion of this course, students will be certified to rent our exclusive Stand Up Paddle boards. Come prepared! (Towel, water shoes, sunscreen, food, water bottle, swimsuit, sunglasses & hat)

title: Inclusive Customer Service
eventDescriptions: "The way we interact with our customers goes a long way in creating a safe and inclusive environment. This training will discuss ways to engage your community members with services that are welcoming to all. Participants will discuss how to build cultural fluency and navigate conflict in a professional and inclusive manner that meets the unique needs of each customer. Learning Objectives: After completing this training, participants will be able to: - Identify the core principles of inclusive customer service - Understand strategies for inclusively serving diverse populations - Reflect on and practice navigating conflict in customer service in an inclusive manner Level: Beginner Modality: Lecture style with discussion and breakouts"

title: CHYLA General Meeting: In-Person
eventDescriptions: Join us for our CHYLA general meeting open to everyone! We will meet monthly, alternating meeting on Zoom and in-person (check Campus Events Calendar and our website for in-person meeting location). We look forward to sharing space and getting to know you! Join our email list to stay updated on meeting and events.  Please inquire about leadership and mentoring opportunities today!  The Chicana/x Y Latina/x Mentoring Network (CHYLA Mentoring Network) is a community-building group made up of staff, administrators, and student employees, from California State University, Sacramento (the “University”) and its auxiliaries (University Enterprises, Inc., Capital Public Radio, Union WELL, and Associated Students, Inc.). The CHYLA Mentoring Network was created to develop a space for Chicanas/x and Latinas/x throughout the University and its auxiliaries to build community; support each other’s professional and personal goals; build their network; create mentorships, and to amplify the call to address underrepresented Chicanas/x and Latinas/x in leadership.

eventDescriptions: Join CHLFSA for the much-anticipated release of "Erendira: A Novel" by Sac State's own Dr. Rose Borunda, who will read from her newest publication. title: Weekly Dose of Mindfulness
eventDescriptions: "Weekly Dose of Mindfulness is an opportunity for all CSU community members to experience guided mindfulness practices with a trained facilitator. Mindfulness can be defined as paying attention, on purpose, to the present moment, with kindness and curiosity. These 30-minute sessions, held twice a week, focus on practices that will reduce stress and anxiety and improve overall wellbeing of our staff. The goal of this series is to offer evidence-based mindfulness tools that research has demonstrated can help: (i) Quiet the habitual chatter of the mind; (ii) (ii) Cultivate a capacity for deep awareness; (iii) (iii) Reduce emotional reactivity; (iv) (iv) Increase feelings of connectedness, compassion and belonging; (v) (v) Help staff thrive and develop resilience in an uncertain and rapidly changing world. (vi) No prior experience is necessary. Join us at csusm.zoom.us…"

title: An Evening with Clio
eventDescriptions: An Evening with Clio: Clio, Sac State's student-run history journal, is produced by undergraduate and graduate students who are invested in creating a publication that reflects our diverse campus community. In 2024, Clio won first place in the Phi Alpha Theta History Honor Society competition for student history journals. For this event, we intend to showcase the production of the journal through the presentation board display of various aspects of student activity on the current edition in production: selection process, cover art and design, book reviews, fundraising, KSSU commercial, and the abstracts of selected papers. There will also be a panel discussion with current and former editors of the journal, followed by a reception open to students, families, alums, and the community. This will be an educational and celebratory event that focuses on the art of writing and publishing history.

title: The Shape of Power: STORIES OF RACE AND AMERICAN SCULPTURE
eventDescriptions: Dr. Karen Lemmey, The Lucy S. Rhame Curator of Sculpture at the Smithsonian American Art Museum, presents a lecture on this groundbreaking exhibition. Explore how artists across generations have transformed diverse materials into powerful social commentary, creating essential frameworks for understanding today's urgent conversations about race, identity, and justice in America. After the lecture, Jennifer Wagelie, PhD, from Sac State’s Office of Inclusive Excellence, will engage Dr. Lemmey in a conversation about art as a vital tool for navigating our challenging times.

title: Passover (Pesach) (Jewish)
eventDescriptions: Pesach is a week-long observance commemorating the freedom and exodus of the Israelites (enslaved Jews) from Egypt during the reign of the Pharaoh Ramses II.  Common practices include Family gatherings, ritualized meals called Seders, reading of the Haggadah, and additional dietary restrictions. Passover is a time of reflection on freedom, resilience, and the ongoing struggle for justice and dignity. Common Accommodations: Avoid scheduling important academic deadlines, events, and activities on the first two and last two days.

title: The 31st Annual Multicultural Education Conference: Nurturing Pedagogies of Collective Healing
eventDescriptions: The 31st annual MCE conference is an invitation to collectively reflect on the ways in which we can heal from the violences reproduced through dominant educational institutions and to find respite and hope through community-rooted pedagogies (Serrano et al., 2022). We believe it is imperative to gather to learn from the rich wisdom of cultural knowledge, practices, pedagogies of the home (Delgado Bernal, 2001) and pedagogies that exist within our communities. We know that education can be a space a flourishing when we lean on culturally rooted and affirming practices that create belonging, relevance, and restorative educational spaces. We invite you, current students, staff, faculty, alumni, community educators and organizers to consider how you are cultivating healing-spaces in your own educational contexts so that we may learn from one another. In envisioning this theme, we were inspired by the questions: How do we heal from the violences that are reproduced through dominant modes of schooling? How do we co-create and sustain our freedom dreams? What pedagogies support a praxis of healing and freedom dreaming?

title: Guest Artist: Richard Leiter
eventDescriptions: Jingle writer, pianist, and historian Richard Leiter presents his popular "Jazz Stories" series. His show features some of the most exciting musical talent in the Bay Area, who have been playing to packed houses monthly for the last ten years in Berkeley, California. Featuring: Richard Leiter (keyboard/vocals), John Hoy (guitar), Greg Johnson (saxophone), Dick Bright (violin), and Jerwayne Macklin (drums). As a composer, Richard Leiter has created and produced music, songs and jingles for hundreds of TV & radio projects for clients like Honda, Citibank, FOX/TV, Mattel, Carl's Jr., Wal-Mart, Warner Bros., Disney, Tropicana, Trump's Castle, Kawasaki, ABC/TV and National Public Radio. For ten years he wrote the award-winning monthly Composing column for Keyboard Magazine. His music has won first place in the ANDY, ADDY, CLIO, Silver Microphone and Belding competitions. His song for Lucky Supermarkets ("So Nice, Low Price Store") won the First Prize in the International Broadcasting Awards. As a keyboard performer you may have heard Rich playing the jazz piano tracks on one of the recent CBS Charlie Brown "Peanuts" Specials, and the Met Life, Snickers, or Shell "Snoopy" commercials. His playing and singing have also been featured in projects for the Sheraton Hotels. Tropicana, Paramount Pictures as well as projects for NBC and CBS.

title: Basic Powerboating Class -02
eventDescriptions: Course includes instruction on the why and how of safe power boating. Time is split between classroom and practical "hands on" experiences using our fleet of training vessels. This is a basic introductory class where all boating is done at low speed. The classroom will cover the rules of navigation, anatomy of a vessel, theory of small boat engines and propulsion, knots, and seamanship. On the water practical will cover basic maneuvering and handling, docking, and disembarking, and man overboard drills. California Department of Boating and Waterways safety course certificate is included.

title: Business Writing in the Age of AI: Risks and Rules for AI Tools
eventDescriptions: ​Tempted to try AI to enhance your business writing? Whether you’re writing formal business documents, research papers, letters, email messages, or social media posts, business writing can be painful and time-consuming. Writers increasingly turn to AI to speed the process, generate content, and enhance communications. When it comes to business writing, artificial intelligence works best when combined with human intelligence. In other words, consider risks and establish rules before adopting AI tools. This session is designed for those seeking to enhance their business writing with the help of AI. Writing Coach Nancy Flynn will share the pros & cons and dos & don’ts of AI writing tools. You’ll leave with a strategy for creating clear, compelling, correct business documents—with a hand from AI.​ Link to Register

title: Carlsen Center Startup Board Development Series
eventDescriptions: The Carlsen Center for Innovation & Entrepreneurship is excited to offer the Startup Board Development Series which will enable you, as a founder, to unlock the hidden power of startup and advisory boards. This three-part series will be led by Kim Box, Independent Board Director and Advisor as well as Carlsen Center Advisory Board Member. Workshop 1 – Board Overview (April 8th) The overview will take into consideration different stages of the company: Seed Growth Series A+ Acquisition or IPO Explore the role of a board or advisory board Support you in identifying who should be on your board The blocking and tackling of setting up a board Workshop 2 – Board Mechanics (April 15th) The focus will be on all aspects of running the board: Calendar – cadence of board meetings Who attends beyond the board members Agenda Board Packet How to effectively communicate and engage a board An effective strategy for structuring your board or advisory board Workshop 3 – Panel with Board Members and Founders (April 22nd) We will bring in a panel of board members and founders to share their real-world experience in building and serving on advisory and startup boards.

title: New Millennium Series: Owls Quartet
eventDescriptions: BUY TICKETS >> Owls is a fresh and original new string quartet collective featuring some of chamber music’s most creative voices. All of the ensemble’s repertoire is arranged specially for the group’s unusual forces of two cellists instead of two violinists, “a process that may account for Owls’ evident deep investment in each work they play” (The New York Times). The program features two pieces by cellist Paul Wiancko (also of Kronos Quartet), alongside works by Azerbaijani composer Franghiz Ali-Zadeh, minimalism pioneer Terry Riley, jazz legend Chick Corea, indie rock duo Trollstilt, and French Baroque composer François Couperin. title: Weekly Dose of Mindfulness
eventDescriptions: "Weekly Dose of Mindfulness is an opportunity for all CSU community members to experience guided mindfulness practices with a trained facilitator. Mindfulness can be defined as paying attention, on purpose, to the present moment, with kindness and curiosity. These 30-minute sessions, held twice a week, focus on practices that will reduce stress and anxiety and improve overall wellbeing of our staff. The goal of this series is to offer evidence-based mindfulness tools that research has demonstrated can help: (i) Quiet the habitual chatter of the mind; (ii) (ii) Cultivate a capacity for deep awareness; (iii) (iii) Reduce emotional reactivity; (iv) (iv) Increase feelings of connectedness, compassion and belonging; (v) (v) Help staff thrive and develop resilience in an uncertain and rapidly changing world. (vi) No prior experience is necessary. Join us at csusm.zoom.us…"

title: The Thinking Game - Film Viewing
eventDescriptions: The Carlsen Center for Innovation & Entrepreneurship is excited to partner with the National Institute on Artificial Intelligence in Society in bringing this film viewing of The Thinking Game to you. "The Thinking Game takes you on a fascinating journey into the heart of DeepMind, one of the world’s leading AI labs, as it strives to unravel the mysteries of artificial general intelligence (AGI).Inside DeepMind’s London headquarters, founder Demis Hassabis and his team are relentlessly pursuing the creation of AI that matches or surpasses human abilities on a wide range of tasks. Filmed over five years, the documentary puts viewers in the room for the pivotal moments of this quest, including the groundbreaking achievement of AlphaFold, a program that solved a 50-year grand challenge in biology. This film captures the exhilaration of historic breakthroughs like AlphaFold, the crushing weight of disappointment during setbacks, and the unwavering pursuit of knowledge that defines Demis’ commitment to scientific innovation. This film invites viewers to witness one of the most important scientific adventures of our time, exploring the potential of AGI to reshape our world." If any special accommodations are needed please let us know at least two weeks in advance to secure the needed accommodations.

title: Basic Sailing Keelboat Class - 02
eventDescriptions: The Holder 20 Keelboat is our largest and most stable boat with boat mainsail and jib.  As with the Quest, it requires two people to rent (only one person needs to be certified.)  Three to five students will be grouped for on the water training.  With its larger cockpit and bench style seating the keelboat can accommodate four to six adults and is the best choice for those who want a less physically demanding boat. There is no capsize recovery required as the boat is extremely unlikely to capsize

title: Carlsen Center Startup Board Development Series
eventDescriptions: The Carlsen Center for Innovation & Entrepreneurship is excited to offer the Startup Board Development Series which will enable you, as a founder, to unlock the hidden power of startup and advisory boards. This three-part series will be led by Kim Box, Independent Board Director and Advisor as well as Carlsen Center Advisory Board Member. Workshop 1 – Board Overview (April 8th) The overview will take into consideration different stages of the company: Seed Growth Series A+ Acquisition or IPO Explore the role of a board or advisory board Support you in identifying who should be on your board The blocking and tackling of setting up a board Workshop 2 – Board Mechanics (April 15th) The focus will be on all aspects of running the board: Calendar – cadence of board meetings Who attends beyond the board members Agenda Board Packet How to effectively communicate and engage a board An effective strategy for structuring your board or advisory board Workshop 3 – Panel with Board Members and Founders (April 22nd) We will bring in a panel of board members and founders to share their real-world experience in building and serving on advisory and startup boards.

title: Somatic Movement Class
eventDescriptions: Join instructor Heather Foli in this group fitness class to explore movements that gently engage the multiple nervous system states, support trauma healing, and encourage a deeper sense of embodiment. Somatic movement practices are designed to be accessible for all bodies, with an emphasis on creating safety, listening to your own pace, and building resilience in both body and mind. title: Japanese Tea Gathering
eventDescriptions: Tea Gatherings are offered throughout the semester at the Sokiku Nakatani Tea Room and Garden. The tea room and garden provide a unique and essential way for students and community members to study Japanese aesthetics and traditional arts, built particularly around the time-honored art form of Chado, the Way of Tea. The Sokiku Nakatani Tea Room and Garden provides direct experiential knowledge of Japanese culture through participatory educational experiences and promotes multicultural and interdisciplinary perspectives through programming designed to increase cultural understanding and to be a space where all may experience peace and tranquility in an experiential environment. Register to attend at the link below.

title: Denim Day Engagement & Resource Fair
eventDescriptions: Denim Day has been observed worldwide in April since 1999. It started after the Italian Supreme Court overturned a rape conviction because the victim wore tight jeans. Each year, we continue to wear denim to show support for survivors of sexual violence and take a stand to show that clothing does not equal consent. Join us in the Library Quad for the Denim Day Engagement & Resource Fair to decorate denim in support of Sexual Assault Awareness Month, take a pledge to keep our campus free of sexual violence, and participate in other important activities.

title: Yom HaShoah - Holocaust Remembrance Day (Jewish)
eventDescriptions: Yom HaShoah, or Holocaust Remembrance Day, is a solemn day of commemoration for the six million Jews murdered during the Holocaust, as well as the courage of survivors and resistance fighters. Observed primarily in Israel and Jewish communities worldwide, it typically includes memorial ceremonies, moments of silence, and educational programs to honor the victims and reflect on the lessons of history. Yom HaShoah serves as a reminder of the importance of combating hatred, preserving memory, and promoting human dignity. This is the traditional Jewish observance of Holocaust Remembrance, not to be confused with International Holocaust Remembrance Day on January 27.

title: Weekly Dose of Mindfulness
eventDescriptions: "Weekly Dose of Mindfulness is an opportunity for all CSU community members to experience guided mindfulness practices with a trained facilitator. Mindfulness can be defined as paying attention, on purpose, to the present moment, with kindness and curiosity. These 30-minute sessions, held twice a week, focus on practices that will reduce stress and anxiety and improve overall wellbeing of our staff. The goal of this series is to offer evidence-based mindfulness tools that research has demonstrated can help: (i) Quiet the habitual chatter of the mind; (ii) (ii) Cultivate a capacity for deep awareness; (iii) (iii) Reduce emotional reactivity; (iv) (iv) Increase feelings of connectedness, compassion and belonging; (v) (v) Help staff thrive and develop resilience in an uncertain and rapidly changing world. (vi) No prior experience is necessary. Join us at csusm.zoom.us…"

title: Practicing Leadership in Hectic Times - Part 1: Understanding and Using Authority
eventDescriptions: Many people believe leadership is about amassing the most power and being in charge of people. While using authority can be an important part of practicing leadership, the concepts are also distinct. This session (the first of two) will discuss concepts and functions of authority, how authority relates to leadership, and strategies for using authority effectively in our work.

title: Pt. Reyes Backpacking
eventDescriptions: Embark on a multi-day backpacking expedition through the rugged beauty of Point Reyes National Seashore. Backpacking in Point Reyes National Seashore is an extraordinary adventure that allows backpackers to fully immerse themselves in the untamed beauty of this coastal wilderness. With its backcountry trails and remote campsites, backpackers can explore hidden coves, traverse rolling hills, and witness breathtaking sunsets over the Pacific Ocean, creating unforgettable memories in one of California's most cherished natural treasures. Disconnect from the distractions of everyday life, forge deep connections with nature, and challenge yourself both mentally and physically. This immersive outdoor adventure fosters personal growth, resilience, and a profound appreciation for the world's natural wonders. Activity Level 3 Transportation, food, needed gear, permits, and transportation included Cost: Student: $199 Affiliate: $259 General Public: $299

title: Recognizing the Impact of World Events on the Workplace
eventDescriptions: One of the many ways workplaces can be more inclusive and create a sense of belonging is by recognizing the impact of world events on people’s lives and work. This is especially important in diverse teams (which all of our teams are) because something that is deeply impactful for one person may barely register with another. At the same time, it can be challenging to keep up with the seemingly constant stream of news, disasters, and troubling events that happen on a daily basis. This session will discuss the pro-active measures people and teams can take to be supportive and identify strategies and resources to mobilize if and when people on our team are impacted.

title: Take Back The Night
eventDescriptions: Take Back the Night is an annual march through campus to empower survivors and advocate for an end to sexual violence. Take Back the Night started as a protest in March of 1972, when women began marching on their campuses together in an organized and intentional manner, demanding a less violent future. At Sac State, we continue to march each year to show support for survivors of sexual violence, to encourage bystander intervention, and to take a stand for a safe and empowered campus. All are welcome and encouraged to attend. Registration is suggested but not required.

title: Take Back the Night –March Through Campus
eventDescriptions: Take Back the Night is an annual march through campus to empower survivors and advocate for an end to sexual violence. Take Back the Night started as a protest in March of 1972, when women began marching on their campuses together in an organized and intentional manner, demanding a less violent future. At Sac State, ALL members of the campus community are invited to march each year to show support for survivors of sexual violence, to encourage bystander intervention, and to take a stand for a safe and empowered campus. Registration is suggested but not required. Registration: The student group/club/team that registers the most members will receive a gift of appreciation. Take a pledge of support and/or register here. Speakers Invited-- If you or someone you know is a survivor of sexual assault or relationship violence, and speaking about the experience might bring empowerment and awareness to others, please consider submitting your story through this speaker recruitment form. title: Practicing Leadership in Hectic Times - Part 2: Exploring and Practicing Leadership
eventDescriptions: Almost everyone defines leadership differently. Hectic moments and times of crisis can bring into focus when leadership is needed and often highlight where it has been missing within teams and organizations. This session (second of two) will offer opportunities for attendees to examine the differences between leadership and authority, identify the work necessary to sustain leadership, and practice applying leadership to hectic moments that can arise in their departments.

title: Weekly Dose of Mindfulness
eventDescriptions: "Weekly Dose of Mindfulness is an opportunity for all CSU community members to experience guided mindfulness practices with a trained facilitator. Mindfulness can be defined as paying attention, on purpose, to the present moment, with kindness and curiosity. These 30-minute sessions, held twice a week, focus on practices that will reduce stress and anxiety and improve overall wellbeing of our staff. The goal of this series is to offer evidence-based mindfulness tools that research has demonstrated can help: (i) Quiet the habitual chatter of the mind; (ii) (ii) Cultivate a capacity for deep awareness; (iii) (iii) Reduce emotional reactivity; (iv) (iv) Increase feelings of connectedness, compassion and belonging; (v) (v) Help staff thrive and develop resilience in an uncertain and rapidly changing world. (vi) No prior experience is necessary. Join us at csusm.zoom.us…"

eventDescriptions: One of the most important numbers consumers have is their credit score: it affects the ability to purchase a home, buy a car, get a credit card, and other financial decisions. title: Angel Island Bike Tour
eventDescriptions: Embark on a scenic bike tour around Angel Island, embracing the beauty of the San Francisco Bay. Angel Island is a pristine natural sanctuary located in the San Francisco Bay, known for its rich history and captivating beauty. This island preserves a tapestry of diverse ecosystems and bears witness to the stories of Native American tribes, immigrants, and soldiers who left their mark on its shores throughout the centuries. Pedal along the waterfront, soak in panoramic views and revel in the sense of freedom that comes with exploring the great outdoors. This outdoor adventure combines wellness, community, and a chance to embrace the joy of discovery in an inspiring, outdoorsy setting.  Bikes, transportation, guides, and ferry tickets included  Activity level 2 Cost:  Student: $79 Affiliate:$109 General Public: $119

title: Exposing Hidden Bias
eventDescriptions: "Join us for an important discussion that brings attention to the unconscious biases we all possess and provides some strategies for overcoming its impact in our work and relationships. Come learn about diversity & inclusion, how to recognize areas where unconscious bias may surface, identify strategies for avoiding bias, and learn of resources available for additional learning and involvement.This workshop is for those interested in building awareness of unconscious bias, or looking for a refresher.  During the workshop, we will engage with each other in sharing thoughts, perspectives, and ideas utilizing a variety of zoom tools such as unmute, hand raising, chat field, and breakout rooms.  As such, if able, you are encouraged to turn on your video to connect. Optional Prework -  In order to prepare for some rich conversation, we invite you to participate in the following:      • View the following video from Scientific American Frontiers:  www.youtube.com… • Complete the Race Implicit Association Test (IAT), and in addition, select one of the following: Gender-Career, Disability, Skin-tone, Age or Weight.  The implicit Association Tests are available at:  implicit.harvard.edu… • Read the Roots of Implicit Bias article from New York Times:  nyti.ms… For information about your workshop facilitator, Lanaya Gaberel, please visit the LinkedIn page at www.linkedin.com…"

title: Preparing Teams for Change
eventDescriptions: "Course Title: Preparing Teams for Change Description of Course Content: This workshop focuses on equipping managers and team members with the skills and knowledge needed to coach people through change within their organization. Participants will explore two models of change management, understand the emotional and psychological impacts of change, and learn communication strategies to support teams through transitions. Learning Outcomes/Objectives: • Understand the fundamentals of change management and its importance in the workplace. • Identify common reactions to change and develop strategies to address them. • Learn techniques to communicate change effectively and empathetically to team members. • Develop skills to support individuals and teams during periods of change. • Create a communication sample using the elements of change communication Who is this for: This workshop is designed for team members and managers at all levels. How will the learning take place: The session will include a mix of lecture, interactive discussions, and small group activities. Are there pre-activities: No"

title: CHYLA General Meeting
eventDescriptions: Join us for our CHYLA general meeting open to everyone! We will meet monthly, alternating meeting on Zoom and in-person (check Campus Events Calendar and our website for in-person meeting location). We look forward to sharing space and getting to know you! Please inquire about leadership and mentoring opportunities today! The Chicana/x Y Latina/x Mentoring Network (CHYLA Mentoring Network) is a community-building group made up of staff, administrators, and student employees, from California State University, Sacramento (the “University”) and its auxiliaries (University Enterprises, Inc., Capital Public Radio, Union WELL, and Associated Students, Inc.). The CHYLA Mentoring Network was created to develop a space for Chicanas/x and Latinas/x throughout the University and its auxiliaries to build community; support each other’s professional and personal goals; build their network; create mentorships, and to amplify the call to address underrepresented Chicanas/x and Latinas/x in leadership.

title: Basic Sailing Zest Class - 02
eventDescriptions: The newest addition to our fleet, the Zest sailboat is taught using a mainsail only and can be sailed by one person (single-handed.)  It is the easiest to rig and sail, and compared to the Quest, it is more stable and easier to recover from a capsize. The Zest is 12 feet long, 5 feet wide and weighs 160 pounds.  It is our best option for practicing basic skills and sailing solo if you do not have a partner.  However, it will easily accommodate an adult and a child or two average-sized adults.

title: Lag B’Omer (Jewish)
eventDescriptions: Lag BaOmer is a festive Jewish holiday celebrated on the 33rd day of the Omer, the period of counting between Passover and Shavuot. It marks a break in the semi-mourning customs observed during the Omer. Celebrations include bonfires and outdoor festivities, symbolizing resilience and the light of Jewish spirituality. Lag BaOmer is a joyful day of community and renewal.

title: Order of the Engineer Ring Ceremony
eventDescriptions: The Order of the Engineer Ring Ceremony is a tradition honoring graduating engineering students as they take the "Obligation of an Engineer"—a lifelong pledge to uphold ethical standards and serve humanity through responsible engineering practices. Participants will receive a stainless steel ring, worn on the fifth finger of the working hand, symbolizing their commitment to integrity and professionalism. How to Participate: Sign Up & Ring Sizing: Visit the ECS Dean’s Office (2014 Riverside Hall). Payment: Submit a $15 fee at the Bursar’s Office or online using the ring purchase payment form. Ceremony: Attend the Ring Induction to receive your ring and certificate. This ceremony is a meaningful milestone, celebrating both your achievements and dedication to the engineering profession.

title: Intercultural Creativity®: The Ace Up Your Sleeve for the Future of Work
eventDescriptions: ​Creative thinking is now the #1 skill needed in our workforce. So increasing the creative thinking skills on your teams is no longer a luxury, it’s now required. But creativity can’t thrive unless there is a culture of inclusion, belonging and psychological safety. This interactive session combines intercultural development, which is a key tool needed for inclusion, with a methodology that cultivates and expands creative thinking. We show you how to integrate this into your culture. ​Attendees will learn how: -culture and creativity are connected -to analyze their own cultural behaviors and become aware and beneficially responsive to others. title: Basic Powerboating Class -03
eventDescriptions: Course includes instruction on the why and how of safe power boating. Time is split between classroom and practical "hands on" experiences using our fleet of training vessels. This is a basic introductory class where all boating is done at low speed. The classroom will cover the rules of navigation, anatomy of a vessel, theory of small boat engines and propulsion, knots, and seamanship. On the water practical will cover basic maneuvering and handling, docking, and disembarking, and man overboard drills. California Department of Boating and Waterways safety course certificate is included.

title: Basic Sailing Quest Class - 02
eventDescriptions: The Quest sailboat is taught using a mainsail and a jib and requires two people to rent at the Aquatic Center (only one person need to be certified.)  Students will be paired for on the water training. The Quest is 14 feet long, 6 feet wide and weighs 310 pounds; it is a bit more difficult to balance and recover from a capsize.  Most sailing programs utilize this type of boat; it is suitable for beginners but also for learning more advanced sailing techniques.

title: Hornet Community Bus Tour
eventDescriptions: The Hornet Community Bus Tour (HCBT) is a two-day touring event which familiarizes Sac State faculty, staff, and administration with the communities where they reside, work, and engage in recreational activities. The tour aims to develop meaningful relationships that can lead to a diverse range of opportunities. These include opportunities for students, fostering research collaborations that are mutually beneficial, engaging in projects with community partners, and offering chances to volunteer with different organizations.

title: Sustainable Living - Summer & Home Edition
eventDescriptions: "Join us for an engaging and informative session on sustainable living, tailored specifically for the summer season and home environment. This one-hour training will provide practical tips and strategies to help you reduce your environmental footprint, save money, and create a healthier living space. Course Objectives: • Understand the principles of sustainable living and their importance. • Learn practical ways to conserve energy and water during the summer. • Discover eco-friendly home maintenance and gardening practices. • Explore sustainable food choices and waste reduction techniques. • Gain insights into creating a comfortable and eco-conscious home environment. Key Topics: 1. Energy Efficiency: Tips for reducing energy consumption, including cooling strategies and the use of energy-efficient appliances. 2. Water Conservation: Techniques for minimizing water usage, such as rainwater harvesting and efficient irrigation systems. 3. Eco-Friendly Home Maintenance: Sustainable cleaning products, DIY home repairs, and maintenance tips. 4. Sustainable Gardening: Organic gardening practices, composting, and creating a wildlife-friendly garden. 5. Green Living Tips: Simple lifestyle changes to reduce waste, including recycling, upcycling, and mindful consumption. Who Should Attend: This course is ideal for homeowners, renters, and anyone interested in adopting a more sustainable lifestyle. Whether you're new to the concept of sustainable living or looking to enhance your existing practices, this session will provide valuable insights and actionable steps. Materials Provided: • Digital handouts with tips and resources • A checklist for sustainable home practices Instructor: Our experienced instructor is a sustainability expert with a passion for helping individuals and families live more eco-friendly lives. Juliana brings a wealth of knowledge and practical experience to the session, ensuring you leave with the tools and confidence to make positive changes."

title: Basic Kayaking Class - 02
eventDescriptions: This course is designed to introduce the beginning paddler to the three most widely used recreational kayaks, correct paddling techniques, navigation and safety on Lake Natoma. The first day instruction will start with sit on top Kayaks, then move to a more technical boat called the surf ski. The second day will incorporate all of the skills in a Viking touring boat. Our ACA certified instructors create a friendly, welcoming environment for all participants regardless of age, ability or skill. Once you have completed this course, you are eligible to rent any equipment in which you have shown competence through this course.

title: Stand Up Paddle Class - 04
eventDescriptions: Sign up for one of out stand up paddle board (SUP) clinics and see what all the excitement is about. Even if you have little experience paddling, our group SUP courses are designed using ACA level one requirements, which introduce and expose beginning paddlers to the skills, equipment and knowledge that is needed to become a successful paddle boarder. We also challenge more advanced paddlers wanting to improve their techniques on the water. Upon completion of this course, students will be certified to rent our exclusive Stand Up Paddle boards. Come prepared! (Towel, water shoes, sunscreen, food, water bottle, swimsuit, sunglasses & hat)

title: Self-Coaching 101
eventDescriptions: "The Self Coaching 101 session will explore the mental processes and paradigms that lead to personal and professional excellence. The workshop is based on the idea that a strong mindset if critical to optimal performance and will provide practical tools to allow participants to unlock their fullest potential at home and work. In addition, the session will explore the balance of achievement and fulfillment as keys to long-term success, allowing for increased emotional health and resilience, particularly in these challenging times.   Upon completion of this module, participants will be able to: Understand the Self-Coaching model, with particular emphasis on CTFAR self-coaching structure Develop effective strategies for the monitoring and correction of disempowering paradigms and thought processes, increasing personal satisfaction and performance."

This holiday is marked by evening devotional programs, studying the Torah, and the lighting of the Yahrzeit memorial candle at sundown on the second night of Shavuot.

title: Shavuot (Jewish)
eventDescriptions: In addition to commemorating the receiving of the Torah at Mount Sinai, Shavuot historically marked the time when ancient Israelites brought the Bikkurim (first fruits) of their harvest to the Temple in Jerusalem as an offering of gratitude to God. These offerings included wheat, barley, grapes, figs, pomegranates, olives, and dates—the Seven Species of the Land of Israel. This dual nature of Shavuot underscores its connection to both spiritual revelation and the cycles of agricultural abundance. Accommodations: This is a holiday or custom that may be observed by some members of the Hornet Family. Please note the general practices and common accommodations to ensure that your courses, activities, and events are inclusive and respectful of the multitude of religious and cultural customs observed by our campus community.

eventDescriptions: Come join us for a stunning sunset stand up paddle on beautiful Lake Natoma. This is a chance to be out and paddling on the serene Lake Natoma after the chaos of the day. title: Basic Kayaking Class - 03
eventDescriptions: This course is designed to introduce the beginning paddler to the three most widely used recreational kayaks, correct paddling techniques, navigation and safety on Lake Natoma. The first day instruction will start with sit on top Kayaks, then move to a more technical boat called the surf ski. The second day will incorporate all of the skills in a Viking touring boat. title: Basic Sailing Zest Class - 03
eventDescriptions: The newest addition to our fleet, the Zest sailboat is taught using a mainsail only and can be sailed by one person (single-handed.)  It is the easiest to rig and sail, and compared to the Quest, it is more stable and easier to recover from a capsize. The Zest is 12 feet long, 5 feet wide and weighs 160 pounds.  It is our best option for practicing basic skills and sailing solo if you do not have a partner.  However, it will easily accommodate an adult and a child or two average-sized adults.

title: Big & Bold Paddle - 01
eventDescriptions: Join us for paddling tailored to individuals of all sizes, particularly those in larger bodies, along with their friends and families. No prior paddling experience is needed! We strive to ensure a comfortable, safe, and enjoyable experience for all participants by offering personalized modifications and adaptations based on individual needs. Our aquatic center staff will be on-site to assist with life jacket fittings (we provide jackets up to size 6x), help participants explore a variety of watercraft designed to accommodate higher weight capacities (our boats support up to 500Ibs), and provide water safety education and adaptive paddling techniques. This community-focused program is a wonderful opportunity to build connections, develop paddling skills, and enjoy time on the water in a supportive and empowering environment. Whether you're new to paddling or looking to advance your skills, come and celebrate body liberation while having fun in the great outdoors.

eventDescriptions: Sign up for one of out stand up paddle board (SUP) clinics and see what all the excitement is about. Even if you have little experience paddling, our group SUP courses are designed using ACA level one requirements, which introduce and expose beginning paddlers to the skills, equipment and knowledge that is needed to become a successful paddle boarder. We also challenge more advanced paddlers wanting to improve their techniques on the water. Upon completion of this course, students will be certified to rent our exclusive Stand Up Paddle boards. Come prepared! (Towel, water shoes, sunscreen, food, water bottle, swimsuit, sunglasses & hat)

title: MPP 101: Managing in a Unionized Environment
eventDescriptions: Facilitator: Mark Hyde, Director of Employee Labor Relations Link to register Course Description: Designed to provide tools and resources to managers to develop their foundational managerial skills for optimal impact in their leadership role. The focus is specifically on managing a heavily unionized workforce and how to understand the roles and responsibilities of that environment. We will cover HEERA management, Lead vs. MPP, union access, management rights, etc. NOTE: Open to state-side MPPs only. Status will be verified.  This session will meet in-person or virtually. You must be present for the entire session to receive credit.  You must be registered to be admitted to the session. Registration closes the day before at Noon. Planned accommodations: If you require reasonable accommodations to participate in this event, please notify Learning & Development no later than five (5) business days in advance of this event.

title: Cascade WCM Open Lab Training
eventDescriptions: Join us for a WCM Open Lab. This is a virtual session held on Zoom, where you can join in the call anytime between 2:00 PM and 3:30 PM for hands-on support with your web pages.  Join Zoom Meeting

title: Anne Frank Day (Cultural)
eventDescriptions: Honors Anne Frank’s legacy and her diary’s impact on Holocaust remembrance and human rights. Accommodations: Encourage educational programming and remembrance activities.

title: Loving Day (Cultural)
eventDescriptions: Commemorates the U.S. Supreme Court decision that struck down laws banning interracial marriage. Accommodations: Promote dialogue about diversity and inclusion in relationships.

title: World Day Against Child Labor (Cultural)
eventDescriptions: Advocates for the elimination of child labor and highlights the rights of children. Accommodations: Promote awareness campaigns and educational events.

title: Sunset Paddle - 06
eventDescriptions: Come join us for a beautiful sunset on Lake Natoma and the rise of a full moon. Gently paddling on the waters of Lake Natoma serves as an escape from the rigors of the day. All paddling abilities are welcome. The kayaks are self-bailing so be prepared to get a little wet.

title: Adaptive Sunset Kayaking - 04
eventDescriptions: This program is designed to support a safe and fun adventure for individuals with physical, development, or mental health diagnosis.  Learn beginning paddling skills and have fun with your family or friends.  Adaptive equipment and instruction are provided to create an inclusive environment for all. Come out and get on the water and enjoy Lake Natoma with the Sacramento State Well All In Recreation (AIR Program.)

title: Eid al-Ghadir (Islam)
eventDescriptions: Celebrates the appointment of Ali as the Prophet Muhammad’s successor in Shia Islam. Accommodations: Allow time for prayer and community observance.

title: Giant Sequoia Trees Day Hike
eventDescriptions: Walk through the Valley of the Giants. See the largest trees in the state with Peak Adventures.  Guides and all transportation included.  Activity level 2 Cost: Student: $79  Affiliate: $109  General Public: $119

title: Masters Coached Rowing Program
eventDescriptions: Adult rowing program practice

title: Introduction to Outrigger Canoe - 03
eventDescriptions: Paddlers are introduced to the basics of paddling technique, canoe mechanics, and extending their skills to various seat positions in the canoe. For example, they may be encouraged to try the “stroke” seat that sets the crew’s pace; they may also develop some basic skills as a steers person, learning to navigate the canoes from point to point.

title: Basic Sailing Quest Class - 03
eventDescriptions: The Quest sailboat is taught using a mainsail and a jib and requires two people to rent at the Aquatic Center (only one person need to be certified.)  Students will be paired for on the water training. The Quest is 14 feet long, 6 feet wide and weighs 310 pounds; it is a bit more difficult to balance and recover from a capsize.  Most sailing programs utilize this type of boat; it is suitable for beginners but also for learning more advanced sailing techniques.

title: Big & Bold Paddle - 02
eventDescriptions: Join us for paddling tailored to individuals of all sizes, particularly those in larger bodies, along with their friends and families. No prior paddling experience is needed! We strive to ensure a comfortable, safe, and enjoyable experience for all participants by offering personalized modifications and adaptations based on individual needs. Our aquatic center staff will be on-site to assist with life jacket fittings (we provide jackets up to size 6x), help participants explore a variety of watercraft designed to accommodate higher weight capacities (our boats support up to 500Ibs), and provide water safety education and adaptive paddling techniques. This community-focused program is a wonderful opportunity to build connections, develop paddling skills, and enjoy time on the water in a supportive and empowering environment. Whether you're new to paddling or looking to advance your skills, come and celebrate body liberation while having fun in the great outdoors.

title: All Saints Day (Christian - Eastern)
eventDescriptions: Honors all saints in the Eastern Orthodox tradition. Accommodations: Be mindful of observances and provide flexibility.

title: Father’s Day (Cultural)
eventDescriptions: Celebrates fathers and father figures for their contributions to families and society. Accommodations: Provide flexibility for family celebrations.

title: Trinity Sunday (Christian - Western)
eventDescriptions: Observes the Christian doctrine of the Holy Trinity, celebrated with special church services. Accommodations: Allow time for participation in services.

title: Martyrdom of Guru Arjan Dev (Sikh)
eventDescriptions: Commemorates the martyrdom of the fifth Sikh Guru, who stood for religious freedom. Accommodations: Provide time for reflection and religious observances.

title: Summer Camp Week #3
eventDescriptions: The Aquatic Center offers summer camp for children ages 7-17 in our Basic Camp, Sailing Camp, and Rowing Camp. Space is limited and camps fill quickly! Visit our website for more information.

title: Capital Crew Intro Clinic - 01
eventDescriptions: This clinic for high school students is a great introduction to the sport of rowing for those interested in joining Capital Crew in fall.  Participants will be taught boat safety and handling, introductory stroke technique, the importance of rowing as a team and work on gaining fitness.  After finishing the clinic students will be prepared to join Capital Crew in the fall.

title: Basic Sailing Zest Class - 04
eventDescriptions: The newest addition to our fleet, the Zest sailboat is taught using a mainsail only and can be sailed by one person (single-handed.)  It is the easiest to rig and sail, and compared to the Quest, it is more stable and easier to recover from a capsize. The Zest is 12 feet long, 5 feet wide and weighs 160 pounds.  It is our best option for practicing basic skills and sailing solo if you do not have a partner.  However, it will easily accommodate an adult and a child or two average-sized adults.
